title: RedLine Stealer: The Telegram Exfiltration
summary: Analysis of a .NET stealer exfiltrating credentials to Telegram. Deobfuscation of the XOR routines.
intro: Specimen obtained from a 'shipping invoice' phishing campaign targeting HR departments. The initial payload was a highly obfuscated .NET binary that bypasses static signatures by using dynamic API resolution.

steps.title: 01. Initial Access & Unpacking
steps.content: The sample 'Invoice_Scan_992.exe' is a 600MB padded binary (to evade sandbox size limits). Using dnSpy, we identified the entry point which immediately decrypts a second stage payload from the resource section using AES-256.

steps.title: 02. Config Extraction
steps.content: The unpacked payload contained the C2 configuration encoded with Base64 + XOR. After writing a small Python decoder, we extracted the C2 IP and the Telegram Bot ID used for data exfiltration.

steps.title: 03. Data Theft Capabilities
steps.content: The malware specifically targets 'Login Data' and 'Cookies' files from Chrome, Edge, and Brave. It also scans for 'wallet.dat' files in AppData to steal crypto keys before self-deleting.

title: AsyncRAT Persistence Hunting
summary: Tracking down a fileless persistence mechanism involving Scheduled Tasks and PowerShell.
intro: A client reported slow performance and random pop-ups. We identified a hidden Scheduled Task executing a base64 encoded PowerShell script every hour.

steps.title: 01. Registry Analysis
steps.content: Autoruns revealed a suspicious entry in HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run. The value was not a file path, but a script block invoking a hidden process.

steps.title: 02. Payload Decoding
steps.content: Decoding the base64 string revealed the AsyncRAT client connecting to a dynamic DNS domain. It had capabilities to record the screen and log keystrokes.
